awd_titl_txt: Dissecting An Intrinsic Regulatory Program For Neuronal Polarization In An Invertebrate Chordate
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the processes by which brain cells form and ultimately connect to one another to ensure proper brain function. The experiments use tunicates, the invertebrate animals most closely related to vertebrates, both because they are especially suitable for the technical aspects of this work, and because their neurons share many genes and structural features in common with vertebrates, including humans. The work will be carried out using novel genetic engineering techniques that specifically target brain cells in order to collect novel information about the development of nerve cell features that control the directionality of information flow in nervous systems. This project will also engage high school and college students by teaching them to use these advanced genetic techniques to better understand the networks of genes involved in animal brain development and function.

The work will study the functions of both intracellular and extracellular components of an intrinsic, potentially conserved regulatory program for neuronal polarization and axon outgrowth in the simple chordate Ciona. This project is designed to achieve two main objectives: 1) To arrive at a better mechanistic understanding of the way(s) that intracellular and extracellular cues are integrated to instruct neuronal polarity in vivo; and 2) To elucidate the transcriptional network(s) regulating neuronal polarity in development. This project will deepen our understanding of evolutionarily conserved molecular pathways that coordinating polarized morphogenetic processes in differentiating neurons, as well as the regulatory mechanisms that control cellular morphogenesis in neural development. This research plan is integrated with specific research-related activities to enhance both the biological education that university undergraduates and high school students receive, as well as their appreciation for how fundamental research and comparative animal studies contribute to scientific knowledge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The simple larvae of our closest invertebrate relatives, tunicates, can serve as a powerful model for studying how the brain develops and how its cells "wire" together correctly. The larva of the tunicate Ciona has the smallest central nervous system known to us, with only 177 neurons. For this project, we initialy proposed to study the development of one particular type of brain cell, or neuron, the descending decussating neurons (ddNs). Our aim was to study the ddN as a model for how genetic sequences direct the proper development and connectivity of a neuron.

Our hypothesis was that a genetic program activates the production of both extracellular components (proteins released by the neuron) and intracellular factors (proteins that stay inside the neuron) that together help direct the neuron where to make connections to other cells in the nervous sytem. We also hypothesized that this genetic program was controlled by a key DNA-binding transcription factor protein called Pax3/7. Given how closely related tunicates are to vertebrates, there is ample evidence that much of this genetic program might be shared even with humans.

For the extracellular component, our main target was Netrin1. Despite having identified a role for this protein in guiding ddN directional growth before, we were unable to reveal much further about its mechanism. However, we did identify a novel role for another extracellular component, a short protein which we named Ddpep (ddN-expressed Peptide). For the intracellular components, we pursued various leads mostly relating to proteins that might be stabilizing the cell's "skeleton", or cytoskeleton, especially the network of microtubules that provides support and structure to the cell. We showed that one such microtubule-stabilizing protein, Nckap5, is required for proper directional growth, as predicted. Nckap5 proteins are also found in human cells, suggesting this protein might play similar roles in vertebrate brains.

Where the most progress was made was in dissecting the genetic program that turns on Ddpep, Nckap5, and many other important factors for ddN development. We showed that a network consisting of DNA-binding transcription factors with Pax3/7 at the top is indeed controlling the activation of this program in the ddNs. Pax3/7 does so both directly turning on some genes but also indirectly through its intermediary Pou4. We showed that certain aspects of this program is active in other cells, directing similar but distinct programs. These include neural tube closure and sensory neuron development, both of which are processes that are also shared with vertebrates.

Finally, we believe our broader impact goals were met, as we worked with high school teacher, high school students, and college students to bring CRISPR/Cas9 techniques to these various classroom settings. We hosted students and teachers in our lab for hands-on CRISPR work, but also engaged remotely with students to design CRISPR tools and analyze data at the height of lab closures during the pandemic. We also ran a CRISPR capstone lab course for undergraduate college students, who successfully knocked out genes and identified one gene important for neuron function, resulting in a paper on which all students in the class were co-authors.
